Electrons and ions Ions and protons

q.t: The half-life of fluorine-18 isotope is T. After time t = 4T the number of fluorine-18 nuclei in a source is N. How many fluorine-18 nuclei have decayed in the time interval from t = 0 to t = 4T?

parts.raw: C 1

q.t: The activity of an alpha-emitting source is 120 kBq. The kinetic energy of each alpha-particle is 4.0 MeV. What is the rate of energy released by the source?

parts.raw: small squares Total 9

q.t: Which of the following statement(s) correctly describe radioactive decay? 1 Radioactive decay can be modelled using dice. 2 Radioactive decay of nuclei is random. 3 Radioactive decay of nuclei is spontaneous.

parts.raw: D 1

q.t: A gamma-ray photon of frequency 6.76 √ó 1022 Hz creates a particle-antiparticle pair. The particle -antiparticle pair have zero kinetic energy. What is the mass of the particle?

parts.raw: A 1

q.t: A potential divider circuit is shown below. V9.0 V The battery has electromotive force (e.m.f.) 9.0 V and negligible internal resistance. At room temperature the potential difference (p.d.) across the thermistor is 4.5 V. The temperature of the thermistor is increased and its resistance decreases by 20% from its previous value. What is the p.d. across the thermistor now?

q.t: A particle is moving at right angles to a uniform magnetic field of flux density B. The particle has mass m, charge q and moves in a circular arc of radius r in the region of the magnetic field. What quantities are required to determine the momentum of this particle?

The diagram below shows two long current-carrying conductors X and Y. X Y The conductors are parallel to each other. Y experiences a force because it is in the magnetic field of X. Which row gives the correct direction of the magnetic field at Y due to X, and the direction of the force experienced by Y due to this field? Direction of magnetic field Direction of force

q.t: A student is investigating the refraction of light by a rectangular glass block. The glass block is surrounded by air. The diagram below shows the path of the light as it enters the block, when it is refracted within the block and when it exits the block. Œ∏ œÜglass block Which statement is correct?

o.t: The angles Œ∏ and œÜ are the same because the glass block is surrounded by air.
The product of sin Œ∏ and the refractive index of glass is a constant.
The refractive index of glass is less than the refractive index of air.
The speed of light is the same in both air and glass.

q.t: A proton of mass 1.67 √ó 10‚Äì27 kg is travelling at a speed of 2.0 √ó 105 m s‚Äì1. The table below shows the mass and speed of four particles A, B, C and D. Particle Mass / kg Speed / 105 m s‚Äì1 Which particle has the same de Broglie wavelength as the proton?

parts.raw: D 1

q.t: A beam of sound of intensity I0 is reflected off the surface of water. The amplitude of the reflected sound is 1 4 the amplitude of the incident sound. What is the intensity of the reflected sound in terms of I0?

parts.raw: A 1

q.t: A small sample of muscle has volume 1.0 cm3 and mass 1.10 g. The speed of ultrasound in the muscle is 1600 m s‚Äì1. What is the acoustic impedance of the muscle?

parts.raw: C 1

q.t: The mass of a proton is mp, the mass of a neutron is mn, and the mass of a hydrogen-3 (13H) nucleus is M. The speed of light in a vacuum is c. Which expression is correct for the binding energy (B.E.) of the hydrogen-3 nucleus?

parts.raw: D 1

q.t: A wire in a circuit obeys Ohm‚Äôs law. Which statement about the wire is linked to this law?

o.t: The current in the wire is directly proportional to the potential difference across it.
The current in the wire is inversely proportional to its resistance.
The resistance of the wire is directly proportional to its length.
The resistance of the wire is inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area.

parts.raw: A 1

q.t: An electron has both mass and charge. The electron has a gravitational field and an electric field around it. Which statement is not correct? SECTION B Answer all the questions.

o.t: Both field patterns look the same.
Both field patterns show parallel field lines around the electron.
Both field strengths obey an inverse square law with distance from the electron.
The direction of both fields is the same at any point around the electron.

parts.raw: B 1 Total 15

q.t: A light-emitting diode (LED) can be used to determine the Planck constant h. When the LED just starts to emit light, the equation below is valid eV = hc Œª where V is the potential difference (p.d.) across the LED, Œª is the wavelength of the light emitted, c is the speed of light in vacuum and e is the elementary charge.

q.t: The diagram below shows two parallel plates, E and C, in an evacuated glass tube. A + ‚Äì6.0 mm 0.30 VE Clight glass tube Plate E is made from potassium, which is sensitive to light. Plate C is not sensitive to light. The separation between the plates is 6.0 mm and the potential difference between the plates is 0.30 V. Light of frequency 6.3 √ó 1014 Hz is incident on plate E. The photoelectrons emitted from this plate have maximum kinetic energy 0.30 eV (4.8 √ó 10‚Äì20 J). The photoelectrons are repelled by the negative plate C. The ammeter reading is zero because these photoelectrons reach plate C with zero kinetic energy.

p.t: Calculate the work function of potassium in eV. work function = eV
This question is about a photoelectron emitted perpendicular to plate E and with an initial kinetic energy of 4.8 √ó 10‚Äì20 J.
Show that the magnitude of deceleration of this photoelectron is 8.8 √ó 1012 m s‚Äì2.
Show that the initial speed of the photoelectron is about 3 √ó 105 m s‚Äì1.
Calculate the time t taken by the photoelectron to travel from plate E to plate C. t = s
Using the axes shown below, sketch a graph of kinetic energy Ek against distance x from plate E. 004.06.0 2.0 3.0 6.0x / mmEk / 10‚Äì20 J4.8
Explain, in terms of photons, what happens to the ammeter reading when light of frequency greater than 6.3 √ó 1014 Hz is now incident on plate E

Carbon-14 nucleus Uranium-235 nucleus Decay mode Beta-minus decay Alpha decay Mass of nucleus / u 14.0 235.0 Radius of nucleus / 10‚Äì15 m 2.9 7.4 Use the data to: ‚Ä¢ describe the composition of the nuclei before and after the decay in terms of hadrons and quarks ‚Ä¢ show that both nuclei have the same density Additional answer space if required

p.t: The diag ram below shows two insulated-copper coils A and B connected in circuits. Both coils are individually wrapped around the same iron rod. Coil A is connected to a cell and a switch. Coil B is connected to a filament lamp. The switch is initially closed and the lamp is off. The switch is then opened. The lamp flashes on for a brief time, and then remains off. Explain these observations in terms of magnetic flux

A student is carrying out an experiment u sing a search coil. long solenoid search coil alternating current supplyŒ∏ The search coil is placed at one end of the solenoid. The plane of the search coil is tilted such that it makes an angle Œ∏ with the central axis of the solenoid. The maximum alternating induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) across the ends of the search coil is E0.
Name an instrument that can be used to determine E0

The equation for E0 is: E0 = KI0ANf sin Œ∏ where I0 = maximum current in the solenoid, A = cross-sectional area of the search coil, N = number of turns of the search coil, f = frequency of the alternating current in the solenoid and K = 4.0 √ó 10‚Äì3 V A‚Äì1 m‚Äì2 s. The magnitude of the induced e.m.f. in the search coil can be determined using Faraday‚Äôs law of electromagnetic induction: e.m.f. = rate of change of magnetic flux linkage In the experiment, angle Œ∏ is changed and E0 measured. Suggest the quantity, or quantities, in the equation E0 = KI0ANf sin Œ∏ linked to 1 the ‚Äòrate‚Äô part of the law 2 the ‚Äòchange of magnetic flux linkage‚Äô part of the law

The student plots a straight-line graph of E0 against sin Œ∏. Determine f, including the absolute uncertainty. Write your value of f to 2 significant figures. I0 = (8.0 ¬± 0.2) A N = 5000 gradient of line = KI0ANf = (0.62 ¬± 0.03) V f = ¬± Hz

o.t: long solenoid is connected to an alternating current supply.

p.t: The diagram below shows a simple capacitor. + + d+ + + ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì+Q0 ‚ÄìQ0 The capacitor consists of two horizontal metal plates in a vacuum. The magnitude of the charge on each plate is Q0. The potential difference (p.d.) between the plates is V0. The capacitor plates have capacitance C0. The separation between the plates is d. The energy stored by the capacitor is E0. The top plate is moved vertically upwards. The new separation between the plates is 2d. The charge on each plate remains the same . The energy stored by the capacitor increases .
Determine the new: 1 capacitance in terms of C0 capacitance = C0 2 p.d. between the plates in terms of V0 p.d. = V0 3 energy stored in terms of E0. energy = E0
Explain, in terms of forces between the plates, why the energy stored increases

q.t: A gamma camera has several important components including a collimator, scintillator and photomultiplier tubes.

The data points plotted by the student are shown below . 100.060.100.12 0.08 12 16 18 20 14 R / MŒ©T / s 1 Draw a best-fit straight line through the data points and use the gradient of this line to determine C. 2 Use your answer in (ii)1 to calculate the permittivity Œµ of the paper. Œµ = F m‚Äì1

State the function of the scintillator
